anchor.surface_text: In 1950, Saurashtra became a Part B State of the Union of India by s. 3 of the Indian Finance Act, 1950, the Indian Income-tax Act was extended to it.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 2 runs thus- In making any assessment under the Indian, Income-tax Act, 1922, all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules of a Part B State relating to income-tax and super- tax or any law relating to tax on profits of business shall be taken into account in companyputing the aggregate depreciation allowance referred to in sub-clause  c  of the proviso to clause  iv  of sub-section 2, and the written down value under clause  b  of sub-section 5, of section 10, of the said Act.

concepts.interpretation: Requires taking into account depreciation under Part B State laws or any law on profits of business tax for WDV computation, irrespective of specific difficulty in case.

anchor.surface_text: The Removal of Difficulties Order was made by the Central Government on December 2, 1950, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, and Section 5 of the Opium and and Revenue Laws  Extension of Application  Act, 1950. We are companycerned in the present case only with s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950. That section runs thus- If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of any of the Acts, rules or orders extended by section 3 or section II to any State or merged territory, the Central Government may, by order, make such provision or give such direction as appears to it to be necessary for removing the difficulty.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Central Govt to issue orders removing difficulties in extending IT Act to Part B States.

issues.text: Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and upon a proper construction of the expression or which would have been allowed to him if the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, was in force in the past in Section 13 5 b of the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 the written down value has to be computed by deduction from the actual cost of depreciation allowance which was allowable under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, even though not claimed?

anchor.surface_text: The question of law which was referred to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act on the application of the Commissioner of Income-tax has therefore been framed thus- Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and upon a proper construction of the expression or which would have been allowed to him if the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, was in force in the past in Section 13 5  b  of the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 the written down value has to be computed by deduction from the actual cost of depreciation allowance which was allowable under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, even though number claimed?

issues.text: Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and on a correct interpretation of the relevant provisions of s. 10 5 b read with the Taxation Laws Part B States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, paragraph 2 and the Notification No. 19 S.R.O.477 dated 9th March 1953 under Section 60A the written down value is to be computed after deducting depreciation allowance which could have been claimed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: referred the following two questions to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act- Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and on a correct interpretation of the relevant provisions of s. 10 5   b  read with the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950, paragraph 2 and the Notification No. 19  S.R.O.477  dated 9th March 1953 under Section 60A the written down value is to be computed after deducting depreciation allowance which companyld have been claimed tinder the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

issues.text: Whether the Notification No. 19 S. R.O. 477 dated 9th March 1953 is ultra vires of the powers of the Central Government?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Notification No. 19  S. R.O. 477  dated 9th March 1953 is ultra vires of the powers of the Central Government? The High Court has answered the second question in the affirmative and the correctness of that is no longer in dispute before us.

issues.text: Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and on a correct interpretation of the relevant provisions of Section 10 5 b of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 read with the Taxation Laws Part B States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950, paragraph 2 and the Notification No. 19 S.R.O.477 dated the 9th March 1953 under section 60A the depreciation availed of by the assessees under the Bhavnagar War Profits Act was a deductible amount in computing the written down value of the assets.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties agree that the real question on which the High Courts view was sought and which has been actually considered by the High Court may be expressed thus- Whether on the above facts and circumstances of the case and on a correct interpretation of the relevant provisions of Section 10  5   b  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 read with the Taxation Laws  Part B States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1950, paragraph 2 and the Notification No. 19  S.R.O.477  dated the 9th March 1953 under section 60A the depreciation availed of by the assessees under the Bhavnagar War Profits Act was a deductible amount in computing the written down value of the assets.

issues.text: Whether paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 applies only when a difficulty is actually experienced in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act in a particular case

anchor.surface_text: He contends however that it is only when a difficulty is actually experienced in giving effect to the Indian Income-tax Act that the provision of the Order can come into operation in a particular case. in the cases now under consideration, he argues, no such difficulty was actually experienced and so, paragraph 2 would have no application.

issues.text: Whether the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is covered by the words 'any law relating to tax on profits of business' in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order so as to require deduction of depreciation availed thereunder

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to Mr. Kolahs main contention that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is not one of the laws depreciation allowed under which has to be deducted under paragraph 2 of this Order. He points out that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act had ceased to be in force long before the Part B State-the United States of Saurashtra-came into existence.

arguments.claim: No deduction should have been made for hypothetical depreciation under Section 13(5)(b) of the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 because no claim was made or could be made under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

arguments.court_reasoning: The phrase creates a statutory fiction assuming the Act was in force and implies a proper claim would have been made, as allowance requires a claim.

arguments.claim: The Ordinance uses 'would have been allowed' not 'would have been allowable', and there is no justification for reading 'if a claim supported by prescribed particulars had been made' into it.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants Mr. Kolah has argued that the Ordinance has not used the words would have been allowable to him but the words would have been allowed to him if a claim supported by prescribed particulars had been made, and there is no justification for reading these words into the Ordinance.

arguments.court_reasoning: The words used are implicit and sufficient; authority presumed to know no allowance without claim, so phrase means assuming proper claim.

arguments.claim: Assessees might choose not to claim depreciation even under the Indian Income-tax Act, so no allowance would occur.

arguments.claim: In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd., 'actually allowed' means allowance given effect to, not merely allowable.

anchor.surface_text: Neither of the two cases cited by Mr. Kolah in support of his argument is of any assistance. In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd. 1 the Calcutta High Court decided that the words actually allowed in s. 10 5   b  of the Indian Income-tax Act as amended by the Income-tax  Amendment  Act  XXIII of 1941  are unambiguous and connote the idea that the allowance was in fact given effect to.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to Mr. Kolahs main contention that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is not one of the laws depreciation allowed under which has to be deducted under paragraph 2 of this Order. He points out that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act had ceased to be in force long before the Part B State-the United States of Saurashtra-came into existence.

arguments.claim: The words 'of a Part B State' apply by ellipsis to 'any law relating to tax on profits of business'.

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Kolah these words of a Part B State were intended to be read also after the words any law in the latter portion and were omitted by way of ellipsis so that the sentence might not appear cumbersome.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or sense are omitted to produce better rhythm or balance in the structure of the sentence. After careful companysideration we have however companye to

arguments.court_reasoning: Deliberate omission to include prior laws of component states; if ellipsis, more words omitted; unnecessary if only Part B laws; contrasts Merged States Order.

arguments.claim: The Removal of Difficulties Order was validly made.

anchor.surface_text: It was in view of this decision that Mr. Kolah conceded that the order was validly made.

arguments.claim: The phrase 'which would have been allowed' implies assuming a proper claim had been made, as no allowance without claim.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the words which according to Mr. Kolah were necessary to give effect to the above intention are implicit in the very language that has been used though they have not been expressly used. The authority which made the Ordinance should be credited with having appreciated the position that no depreciation would have been allowed even if the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, had been in force, if no claim supported by proper particulars had been made.

arguments.claim: Once validly made under s.12 Finance Act, 1950, the Removal of Difficulties Order applies irrespective of particular case difficulties.

anchor.surface_text: The consequence of the Removal of Difficulties Order being validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, is that paragraph 2 of the Order as also the other paragraphs have to be applied and no exception can be made.

arguments.claim: Omission of 'of a Part B State' before 'any law relating to tax on profits of business' is deliberate to include pre-Part B laws of component states.

anchor.surface_text: After careful consideration we have however come to the conclusion that the omission of the words of a Part B State in this paragraph is not by way of ellipsis but a deliberate omission with the intention of including laws which could not be stated to be laws of a part B State but had been laws in the same area at a time before they formed part of a Part B State.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in answering the question referred in these cases out of which Civil Appeals Nos. 599 and 601 have arisen, in the affirmative: written down value under Section 13(5)(b) of the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 has to be computed by deducting depreciation which would have been allowed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 even though not claimed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons we have already given, we are of opinion that the High Court was right in answering the question referred in these cases out of which Civil Appeals Nos. 599 and 601 have arisen, in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The phrase 'which would have been allowed' creates statutory fiction implying proper claim made; words implicit and apt; legislature assumes claim ordinarily made; precedents distinguished.

holdings.text: Paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws (Part B States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1950 applies in all cases once validly made under s.12 Finance Act, 1950, without requiring actual difficulty in each particular case.

anchor.surface_text: The consequence of the Removal of Difficulties Order being validly made under s. 12 of the Finance Act, 1950, is that paragraph 2 of the Order as also the other paragraphs have to be applied and no exception can be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order made on general satisfaction operates per its terms; no per-case difficulty needed; follows Dewan Bahadur Ran Gopal Mills Ltd.

holdings.text: The Bhavnagar War Profits Act is covered by the words 'any law relating to tax on profits of business' in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order, requiring deduction of depreciation availed thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: We have come to the conclusion that the Bhavnagar War Profits Act is within the words any law relating to tax on profits of business in paragraph 2 of the Removal of Difficulties Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deliberate omission of 'of a Part B State' before second phrase includes prior laws of component states; ellipsis rejected; purposive to cover pre-Part B laws; contrasts Merged States Order.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly held that depreciation availed under Bhavnagar War Profits Act deductible in computing written down value under s.10(5)(b) IT Act 1922 read with para 2 Removal of Difficulties Order.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the High Court has rightly decided that the depreciation availed of by the assessee under the Bhavnagar War profits act was a deductible amount

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines application of Order para 2 to War Profits Act depreciation; High Court correct despite invalid notification.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd. 1949 17 I.T.R. 130

anchor.surface_text: Neither of the two cases cited by Mr. Kolah in support of his argument is of any assistance. In Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd. 1 the Calcutta High Court decided that the words actually allowed in s. 10 5   b  of the Indian Income-tax Act as amended by the Income-tax  Amendment  Act  XXIII of 1941  are unambiguous and connote the idea that the allowance was in fact given effect to.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamala Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the words 'actually allowed' in s. 10(5)(b) of the Indian Income-tax Act connote that the allowance was in fact given effect to, and do not mean merely allowable under the law
precedents.cited_holding: The Court rejected a contention of the Income-tax authorities that the expression actually allowed means allowable under the law in force.

precedents.citation: Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-Tax 1950 18 I.T.R. 122

anchor.surface_text: In Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd., v. Commissioner of Income-Tax 1  the Bombay High Court had to construe the words the amount of depreciation applicable and held that as the words were number depreciation allowed but depreciation applicable it was immaterial whether the assessee got any benefit of depreciation in any previous year.

precedents.case_name: Rajaratna Naranbhai Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: the words 'the amount of depreciation applicable' make it immaterial whether the assessee got any benefit of depreciation in any previous year

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ran Gopal Mills Ltd. 1961 2 S. C. R. 318

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ran Gopal Mills Ltd.,  1  this Court held that it was for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in s. 12 bad arisen and then to make such order or give such direction as appeared to it to be necessary to remove the difficultly.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Hyderabad v. Dewan Bahadur Ran Gopal Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: it is for the Central Government to determine if any difficulty of the nature indicated in s. 12 has arisen and then to make such order or give such direction as appears to it to be necessary for removing the difficulty

outcome.relief_summary: All four civil appeals (Nos. 599-602 of 1962) dismissed; High Court judgments upheld on computation of written down value by deducting depreciation allowances under Saurashtra Ordinance and Bhavnagar War Profits Act.
